case_name: State of U.P. and the Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor v. plaintiff-respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1701 of 1971 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 10, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in F.A. from Order No. 187 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1701 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 10, 1971 of the Allahabad High Court in F.A. from Order No. 187 of 1967. N. Dikshit and O. P. Rana, for the appellants.

facts.text: State of U.P. and Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor are defendants in the trial court in the plaintiffs' suit.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the State of U.P. and the Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor  defendants in the trial companyrt in the plaintiff-respondents suit  challenge the judgment and order of a learned Single Judge of the Allahabad High Court, allowing the plaintiff-respondents appeal and setting aside the order of the trial companyrt staying the suit under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted a suit for recovery of Rs. 69,556.27 by way of damages for breach of contract against State of U.P. through Collector of Bijnor as first defendant and Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor as second defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs had instituted a suit for the recovery of Rs. 69,556.27 by way of damages for breach of companytract impleading the, State of U.P.  through the Collector of Bijnor as the first defendant and the Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor as the second defendant.

facts.text: Summons in the suit issued to State of U.P. were served on the District Government Counsel.

anchor.surface_text: The summons in the suit issued to the State of U.P. were served on the District Government Counsel. On September 2, 1966 the said companynsel filed an appearance slip in the companyrt and also put in a formal application praying for one months time for the purpose of filing written statement.

facts.text: On September 2, 1966, District Government Counsel filed appearance slip and formal application for one month's time to file written statement, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: On September 2, 1966 the said companynsel filed an appearance slip in the companyrt and also put in a formal application praying for one months time for the purpose of filing written statement. This prayer was granted.

facts.text: On October 1, 1966, District Government Counsel filed application under s. 34 of Arbitration Act for stay of suit, pleading arbitration clause in agreement and State's willingness to refer to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1 1966 the District. Government companynsel filed an application under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act pleading that there was an arbitration clause In the agreement between the parties to the suit and the State of P. being willing to refer the matter to arbitration tie suit should be stayed.

facts.text: Trial court held dispute subject to arbitration clause, State had not taken steps or filed written statement, so stayed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the dispute was subject to arbitration clause and since the State of U.P. had number taken any steps in the, suit proceedings and had also number filed the written statement the suit was liable to be stayed.

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed to Allahabad High Court, which allowed appeal, set aside stay order, holding District Government Counsel's application for time amounted to step in proceedings under s.34.

anchor.surface_text: So holding the application of the State Government was allowed and the suit stayed. On appeal by the plaintiff the High Court relying on two of its earlier decisions in United Provinces Government v Sri Har Nath  1  and Union of India v. Hans Raj Gupta Co.  2 , held that action of A.I.R. 1957 All. 91 A.I.R. 1949 All, 611. the District Government Counsel in applying for time to file the written statement amounted to taking a step in the proceedings within the meaning of S. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

facts.text: Appellants contend District Government Counsel had no instructions to ask for adjournment for filing written statement, so does not bind State of U.P.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Shri G. N. Dikshit learned companynsel for the State of U.P. strongly companytended that the District Government Counsel had numberinstructions to ask for adjournment for the purpose of filing the written statement and, therefore, his action in applying for adjournment for that purpose cannot bind the State of U.P.

facts.text: Trial court granted stay in its discretion, High Court erred in reversing it.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companytended that the trial companyrt having granted stay in its discretion the High Court was in error in reversing that order and setting it aside on appeal.

facts.text: There was an arbitration clause in the agreement between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1 1966 the District. Government companynsel filed an application under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act pleading that there was an arbitration clause In the agreement between the parties to the suit and the State of P.

facts.text: State of U.P. had not filed written statement before application for stay.

anchor.surface_text: since the State of U.P. had number taken any steps in the, suit proceedings and had also number filed the written statement the suit was liable to be stayed.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no serious infirmity in High Court judgment, dismisses appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there is numberserious infirmity in the impugned judgment of the High Court and we are unable to find any companyent ground I.J.P,. 34 Cal,. 443.  2  AJ.R. 1943 Bom. 228. A.I.R. 1945 All. 24.

facts.text: District Government Counsel is authorized by Code of Civil Procedure to receive summons on behalf of State.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant  State of U.P. . the District Government Counsel is authorised by the Code of Civil Procedure to receive summons on behalf of the State vide ground No. 3 in the petition for special leave.

facts.text: Summons were served on District Government Counsel, presumed accompanied by copy of plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, the District Government companynsel was in fact so served. It is number the appellants case that the summons were number accompanied by a companyy of the plaint in accordance with law and, therefore. the District Government Counsel.

facts.text: District Government Counsel under Order XXVII Rule 2 CPC authorized to act for Government as recognized agent.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the plaint, therefore. must be held to have been duly served on the District Government Counsel who under Order XXVII. Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was authorised to act for the Government and was deemed to be the recognized agent

facts.text: State took benefit of adjournment granted on September 2, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The State took benefit of his appearance and his successful prayer for adjournment of the case by one month for the purpose of filing the written statement.

facts.text: No material on record that counsel had no instructions for adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mohan Behari submitted in reply that there was numbermaterial on the record that the companynsel applying for adjournment on behalf of the State had numberinstructions.

facts.text: September 2, 1966 was fixed in summons for filing written statement.

anchor.surface_text: September 2, 1966 was fixed in the summons for filing written statement. Failure to do so would have entailed companysequences prejudicial to the State Government.

facts.text: Suit is for heavy amount of damages for breach of contract, considerable delay since institution.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view the Icing delay after the institution of the suit and the fact that the suit is for a very heavy amount by way of damages for breach of companytract, it will, in our opinion, be more satisfactory

facts.text: High Court relied on United Provinces Government v Sri Har Nath (AIR 1957 All 91) and Union of India v Hans Raj Gupta Co (AIR 1949 All 611).

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the plaintiff the High Court relying on two of its earlier decisions in United Provinces Government v Sri Har Nath 1 and Union of India v. Hans Raj Gupta Co. 2 , held that action of A.I.R. 1957 All. 91 A.I.R. 1949 All, 611.

facts.text: Appellants cite Punjab State v Moji Ram where Government pleader asked for time without instructions.

In that case on the date fixed by the trial companyrt for appearance of the defendant, the Government pleader, with one Kartar Singh Sub-Divisional Officer, appeared and asked for time to file written statement

staying the suit under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act. The plaintiffs had instituted a suit for the recovery of Rs. 69,556.27 by way of damages for breach of contract impleading the, State of U.P.  through the Collector of Bijnor as the first defendant and the Divisional Forest Officer, Bijnor as the second defendant.

concepts.interpretation: Defendant disentitled to stay if files written statement or takes step in proceedings like applying for adjournment to file written statement; application must be before such step; discretionary power not as matter of course; objective test applies with presumption of knowledge and instructions to counsel.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power of court to stay legal proceedings where there is arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: On October 1 1966 the District. Government counsel filed an application under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act pleading that there was an arbitration clause In the agreement between the parties to the suit and the State of P. being willing to refer the matter to arbitration tie suit should be stayed.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of court to stay legal proceedings where there is arbitration agreement

concepts.interpretation: Stay not automatic upon existence of arbitration clause; defendant must apply before taking steps in suit; steps include actions in aid of suit progress or submitting to jurisdiction on merits.
concepts.unlisted_description: Power of court to stay legal proceedings where there is arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: District Government Counsel who under Order XXVII. Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was authorised to act for the Government and was deemed to be the recognized agent by whom appearances, acts and applications could be made or done on behalf of the Government.

concepts.interpretation: District Government Counsel authorised to act as recognised agent for Government, receive summons, appear, act and make applications; binds the State even if claiming no specific instructions.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rtue of statute to appear, act and make applications on behalf of the Government. Indeed in the present case the District Government Counsel also file

concepts.unlisted_description: Recognized agents and pleaders for Government

concepts.interpretation: Confers general right to sue unless barred; party seeking stay under arbitration must strictly comply with conditions to curtail this right.
concepts.unlisted_description: Courts to try all civil suits unless barred

anchor.surface_text: the liability if any of Morans under S. 230 of the Contract Act has to be ascertained in the light of the surrounding circumstances, we think this is a case in which the hearing of the suit, in the interest of both the parties should not be held up but the dispute should be tried in the civil court

concepts.unlisted_description: Liability of agent signing in own name

concepts.interpretation: Connotes doing something in aid of progress of suit or submitting to court jurisdiction for adjudication of merits; application for time to file WS displays intention to proceed in court; objective test, presumption counsel instructed and has knowledge of arbitration clause.
concepts.unlisted_label: Step in the Proceedings (under Arbitration Act s.34)
concepts.unlisted_description: Actions by defendant precluding stay application

concepts.interpretation: General civil right to sue unless expressly/impliedly barred; strict compliance required to curtail via arbitration stay.
concepts.unlisted_label: Where there is a right, there is a remedy

anchor.surface_text: deemed to be the recognized agent by whom appearances, acts and applications could be made or done on behalf of the Government. The District Government Counsel in the present case was thus fully empowered to appear and act for and on behalf of the Government and also to make applications on its behalf.

concepts.interpretation: District Government Counsel under CPC O27 R2 binds Government; cannot claim unauthorised acts after benefiting from them.

issues.text: Whether any other step was taken in the proceeding as contemplated by s. 34 of the Arbitration Act
Whether the District Government Counsel had instructions to apply for adjournment for filing the written statement and whether his action binds the State of U.P.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1 1966 the District. Government counsel filed an application under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act pleading that there was an arbitration clause In the agreement between the parties to the suit and the State of P. being willing to refer the matter to arbitration tie suit should be stayed. The trial court held that the dispute was subject to arbitration clause and since the State of U.P. had not taken any steps in the, suit proceedings and had also not filed the written statement the suit was liable to be stayed.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in interfering with the trial court's exercise of discretion to grant stay under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act

anchor.surface_text: So holding the application of the State Government was allowed and the suit stayed. On appeal by the plaintiff the High Court relying on two of its earlier decisions in United Provinces Government v Sri Har Nath 1  and Union of India v. Hans Raj Gupta Co.  2 , held that action of A.I.R. 1957 All. 91 A.I.R. 1949 All, 611. the District Government Counsel in applying for time to file the written statement amounted to taking a step in the proceedings within the meaning of S. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

issues.text: Whether there are sufficient grounds for interference under Article 136 of the Constitution
Whether the District Government Counsel under Order XXVII Rule 2 CPC is a recognised agent whose acts bind the Government

anchor.surface_text: District Government Counsel who under Order XXVII. Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was authorised to act for the Government and was deemed to be the recognized agent by whom appearances, acts and applications could be made or done on behalf of the Government.

arguments.claim: District Government Counsel had no instructions to ask for adjournment for filing written statement, so his action cannot bind State of U.P., making stay application competent

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Shri G. N. Dikshit learned counsel for the State of U.P. strongly contended that the District Government Counsel had noinstructions to ask for adjournment for the purpose of filing the written statement and, therefore, his action in applying for adjournment for that purpose cannot bind the State of U.P. with the result that application for stay of proceedings in the suit under S. 34 of the Arbitration Act could not be held to be incompetent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the, Punjab High Court in the case of Moji Ram  supra  is merely to be stated to be rejected. A recognized agent like the District Government Counsel

arguments.claim: Trial court exercised discretion to grant stay reasonably, High Court erred in reversing it

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the trial court having granted stay in its discretion the High Court was in error in reversing that order and setting it aside on appeal. According to this submission the discretion had been exercised by the trial court which could not be considered to be either unreasonable or contrary to any recognised principles and the High Court should, therefore, have upheld it.

arguments.claim: Precedent in Punjab State v. Moji Ram supports: Government pleader asking for time without instructions is not a step in proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The counsel relied in support of his submission on Punjab State v. Moji Ram 1 . In that case on the date fixed by the trial court for appearance of the defendant, the Government pleader, with one Kartar Singh Sub-Divisional Officer, appeared and asked for time to file written statement as instructions with a copy of the plaint had not been received.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: equence. Finally, as a result of the decision of the High Court the only companysequence is that the suit will number have to be tried by a companypet

arguments.claim: Precedent in State of Himachal Pradesh v. Lalchand Shahi: prayer for adjournment by counsel without instructions not a step

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was next placed on State of Himachal Pradesh v. Lalchand Shahi 2  where- it was observed by the learned Judicial Commissioner that no person can be deemed to take any step in a proceeding who is not aware of what the proceedings are and, the prayer for adjournment of the case made by a counsel, who up till the moment of making the request for adjournment had received no instructions from his client, did not amount to taking of a step in the proceeding within S. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the, Punjab High Court in the case of Moji Ram  supra  is merely to be stated to be rejected. A recognized agent like the District Government Counsel

arguments.claim: Precedent in Harbans Lal v. National Fire: oral application for adjournment to get instructions not a step

anchor.surface_text: Harbans Lal v. National Fire General Insurance Co. Ltd. 3  is also a decision by a learned single Judge. of the Punjab High Court. In that case the branch office of the de- fendant company had only received the summons of the suit filed by the plaintiff, a day previous to the date of appearance.

arguments.claim: Johri Mal test: application for time to file WS not automatically a step; must show unequivocal intention to proceed in court; objective test but rebuttable presumption if no instructions

anchor.surface_text: He cited Joharitnal and others v. Fatehchand and others  2   as enunciating correct test in such cases, specifically relying on the following observations at page 71 in para 23 -A On principle and judicial authority, we consider that the following propositions maybe easily deduced An application for time to file written statement or any other similar application should not be treated as a matter of law a step in the proceedings.

arguments.claim: Counsel cannot bind client by unauthorized act like seeking adjournment without instructions

anchor.surface_text: Shri Dikshit submitted that just as a Counsel cannot bind his client by his admission and the client can disown it, similarly the appellant in this case can disown the act of his counsel as unauthorised in seeking adjournment for filing a written statement, on the ground that no instructions had been issued to the Counsel to make such a prayer.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rtue of statute to appear, act and make applications on behalf of the Government. Indeed in the present case the District Government Counsel also file

arguments.claim: No material on record that counsel had no instructions; presume duly empowered

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mohan Behari submitted in reply that there was no material on the record that the counsel applying for adjournment on behalf of the State had no instructions. The counsel, according to the submission, must be presumed to have been duly empowered to take all steps that were necessary to be taken in the court in connection with the proceedings on the date he appeared and filed his appearance slip in the Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the, Punjab High Court in the case of Moji Ram  supra  is merely to be stated to be rejected. A recognized agent like the District Government Counsel

arguments.claim: Prayer for adjournment for WS is step in aid under s.34 (citing Sarat Kumar Ray, Edward Kadsons, Roop Kishore, etc.)

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mohan Behari also relied on Sarat Kumar Ray v. Corporation of Cakutta 1 , Adward Hadbons v. Judggilal 2  and Roop Kishore v. U.P. Government 3  in addition to the two Allahabad judgments referred to in the impugned judgment, for the submission that the prayer for adjournment for filing a written statement is a step in aid as contemplated by s. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

arguments.claim: District Government Counsel's application for time to file WS is step in proceedings under s.34

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the plaintiff the High Court relying on two of its earlier decisions in United Provinces Government v Sri Har Nath 1  and Union of India v. Hans Raj Gupta Co. 2 , held that action of A.I.R. 1957 All. 91 A.I.R. 1949 All, 611. the District Government Counsel in applying for time to file the written statement amounted to taking a step in the proceedings within the meaning of S. 34 of the Arbitration Act.

arguments.claim: No steps taken by State, no WS filed, so stay under s.34

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held that the dispute was subject to arbitration clause and since the State of U.P. had not taken any steps in the, suit proceedings and had also not filed the written statement the suit was liable to be stayed.

arguments.claim: s.34 Arbitration Act: stay not as of course; defendant must apply before WS or other step; step means aid to suit progress or submitting to jurisdiction
General right to sue under s.9 CPC unless barred; strict compliance for stay under s.34
DGC under O27 R2 CPC is recognized agent, authorized to act, appear, apply; binds State

anchor.surface_text: A copy of the plaint, therefore. must be held to have been duly served on the District Government Counsel who under Order XXVII. Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was authorised to act for the Government and was deemed to be the recognized agent

arguments.claim: Specific prayer for time to file WS (not just instructions) by DGC is step in proceedings
State took benefit of adjournment, cannot now disown counsel's authority

anchor.surface_text: The State took benefit of his appearance and his successful prayer for adjournment of the case by one month for the purpose of filing the written statement.

arguments.claim: No sufficient ground for interference under Art 136
Suit better tried in court given delay, heavy amount, complex issues rather than lay arbitrator

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view the long delay after the institution of the suit and the fact that the suit is for a very heavy amount by way of damages for breach of contract, it will, in our opinion, be more satisfactory

holdings.text: There is no serious infirmity in the impugned judgment of the High Court and we are unable to find any sufficient ground for interference under Article 136 of the Constitution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly held that adjournment application was a step under s.34; no error in reversing trial court; precedents distinguished.

holdings.text: Taking other steps in the suit proceedings connotes the idea of doing something in aid of the progress of the suit or submitting to the jurisdiction of the court for the purpose of adjudication of the merits of the controversy in the suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Objective test: prayer for time specifically to file WS shows intention to proceed in court; presumption of knowledge of arbitration clause.

holdings.text: District Government Counsel under Order XXVII Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure was authorised to act for the Government and was deemed to be the recognized agent by whom appearances, acts and applications could be made or done on behalf of the Government.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory authority under CPC; served with summons and plaint copy; fully empowered to appear and apply.

holdings.text: The State took benefit of his appearance and his successful prayer for adjournment... it is hardly open to the State Government to plead that the District Government Counsel was not authorised to seek adjournment on its behalf for this purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The State took benefit of his appearance and his successful prayer for adjournment of the case by one month for the purpose of filing the written statement. In those circumstances, it is hardly open to the State Government to plead that the District Government Counsel was number authorised to seek adjournment on its behalf for this purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No material on record of lack of instructions; presumption of due empowerment; benefited from adjournment avoiding default.

holdings.text: If the appellants application was for adjournment for the purpose of filing written statement, then there is no question of any exercise of discretion by the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the trial companyrts discretion has been erroneously reversed by the High Court is equally devoid of merit. If the appellants application was for adjournment for the purpose of filing written statement, then there is numberquestion of any exercise of discretion by the trial companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion under s.34 exercisable only if application competent; prior step makes incompetent, no discretion arises.

holdings.text: A party seeking to curtail this general right of suit has to discharge the onus of establishing his right to do so and the law curtailing such general right has to be strictly complied with.

anchor.surface_text: A party seeking to curtail this general right of suit has to discharge the onus of establishing his right to do so and the law curtailing such general right has to be strictly companyplied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 CPC confers general right to sue; s.34 stay strict, not as matter of course; must apply before step or WS.

holdings.text: Keeping in view the long delay after the institution of the suit and the fact that the suit is for a very heavy amount by way of damages for breach of contract, it will, in our opinion, be more satisfactory on the whole to have the suit tried in a competent court of law in the normal course rather than by a lay arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping in view the Icing delay after the institution of the suit and the fact that the suit is for a very heavy amount by way of damages for breach of companytract, it will, in our opinion, be more satisfactory on the whole to have the suit tried in a companypetent companyrt of law in the numbermal companyrse rather than by a lay arbitrator who is number bound either by the law of evidence or by the law of procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy: complex issues, delay, heavy stakes better for court than arbitrator; discretionary factor if stay considered.

precedents.citation: J. N. Shah Co. v. Hirachand 5 [...] A.I.R. 1954 Bom, 174

anchor.surface_text: J. N. Shah Co. v. Hirachand 5  is a case where in a summary suit the defendant has filed an affidavit in reply setting out defences and had asked for leave to defend and that was held to amount to a step in proceedings. [...] A.I.R. 1954 Bom, 174.

precedents.case_name: J. N. Shah Co. v. Hirachand
precedents.cited_proposition: filing affidavit for leave to defend in summary suit is a step in proceedings

precedents.citation: Dr. V. R. Vaidra v. Union of India  C.R. 347/67 [...] 1970 Maharashtra Law Journal  notes of case  at p. 12  Case No. 20

anchor.surface_text: In Dr. V. R. Vaidra v. Union of India  C.R. 347/67  decided by the Bombay High Court on April 1, 1970 reported in 1970 Maharashtra Law Journal  notes of case  at p. 12  Case No. 20 , in accordance with the summons the counsel for the defendant prayed for adjournment for filing a written statement.

precedents.case_name: Dr. V. R. Vaidra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: counsel presumed to act under instructions when praying for adjournment; not open to later claim no instructions
precedents.cited_holding: the counsel must be deemed to have prayed for adjournment for filing a written statement under instructions
